comment: Seen over No of years.  This year have largely affected cucumber plants - leaves limp & dying off. Flies appear to do little harm but the larvae feed on root system and bury into seed hollowing them out.

info: Tetranychus urticae (common_names include red spider mite and two-spotted spider mite) is a species of plant-feeding mite that is generally considered a pest.

comment: Pests of cultivated brassicas and feed on mnay wild and cultivated plants in the Crucifera. No species of Pieris, or the family Pieridae, have been recorded in the Falklands and thus likely to have been imported from UK.

description: original insect sample brought in on cabbage on 10/9/13 MOD Airbridge, larvae samples & grub produced. Not all l we think that one may have been host to 1mm ant like flies.

description: Caterpillar - bleached and unable to confirm ID beyond genera.

DNA sequence analysis has now ruled out the pupa as being either_x000d_
Liriomyza sativae Blanchard or L. trifolii (Burgess). Unfortunately, it did_x000d_
not throw up a positive match with a sequence on the on-line databases_x000d_
as an alternative.
comment: Indeed, the results did not even conclusively confirm the pupa as an agromyzid (Diptera: Agromyzidae), although a number of Phytomyza and Liriomyza species had low level sequence homology,
info:
no greater or worse than similar closest matches, species in other_x000d_
dipteran families. Having exhausted all the avenues of enquiry open to me I am afraid_x000d_
that I now have to conclude that I cannot identify the pupa.

description: 1 cm fly - poor condition and mouldy, unable to identify species
comment: The larvae of Fannia species are often associated with dung, droppings or other oragnic-rich decomposing material. Fannia canicularis, the small house fly, is one of the better known species, but based on what I can see this specimen isn't F.cannicularis.
info: though cant be ruled out. F.cannicularis is the only reported species in the Falklands so likely human activity responsible for introducing the insect to the Falkland Ilsands.

description: 1 cm fly - poor condition, unable to identify
1cm size Fly with yellow & black striped thorax
comment: This species is not a plant pest, and is viewed as a benficial insect; the larvae feed on aphids and the adults play a role in plant pollination. However it is not native to the Falklands - or South America - and has not previously been recorded from FI.

description: 3mm sized Spider – orange/yellow legs. No colour markings on thorax. Palps are very visible under microscope.
5mm sized weevil. Reddish in colour
comment: The maize weevil, a tropical/subtropical pest of various cereal grains including of course maize. Thie species has been spread around the world through international commerce.
info: Host: Zea mays

description: A preserved pupa from the family Drosophilidae, known as vinegar flies. Adults required to identify beyond family.
comment: Larvae have a range of feeding habiots depending on the species. Many feed on decaying fruit and vegetation, but the family is large and other species have diverse habits including leaf mining.
info: No dodophilids have been recorded from the Falkland Islands.

description: This is a very large family of hoppers with over 900 species described worldwide. South American genera are not well known and so difficult to identify further.
comment: Non-European leafhoppers are regulated in the EU because many species are important vectors of plant viruses. Many species are also highly invasive and have a high natural dispersal potential.

description: Green 2cm Chrysalis
comment: Most likely either P.rapae or P.napi. Pest of cabbage and other plants. Not from the Falklands

description: Ladybird 5mm black with orangey/white spots

description: Growth of plant is very stunted, leaves are curled and the potatoes are very small. Result: Globodera pallida (Stone) Behrens (Heterodeidae)

Your soil sample has been processed for cyst nematodes. Six viable Globodera_x000d_
pallida and 45 non-viable Globodera sp. adult female cyst nematodes were_x000d_
detected. They were identified using a molecular method.

description: Small raised bumps on surface of skin of potato tuber / Dark brown in colour - Phytomyxea: Plasmodiophorales: Plasmodiophoraceae

powdery scab were observed causing raised legions on the tuber surface. The_x000d_
disease was identified by Dr Paul Beales.

description:
The aphids are dark-brown and covered with fine, silky grey hair. Adults are about 6_x000d_
mm long (from head to end of the abdomen) and the abdomen has a large conical_x000d_
tubercle on its back and from the side is very distinguishable.The young lack the tubercle
comment: The aphid feeds on willow and sallow trees (Salix spp.) and can form dense colonies on the trunk and branches, not on the leaves. If disturbed the aphids kick out their long back legs and wave them about.
info:
The Willow Aphid is one of the lrgest and most spectacular aphids but even so, little is known about its biology, lifecycle and distribution.Both winged and wingless adult_x000d_
females occur and they are parthenogenetic. Temp determines if wings develop.

description: Abdomen 3mm long, brown pale markings
comment: Possible member of Steatoda family (male)

info: Found inside a packet of pancake mix (possibly Red flour beetle?)

comment: found in the bar of the Globe Tavern, Stanley. Only specimen sighted and none found during inspection, sticky traps laid.

location: found on FIPASS, likely came from visiting vessel.

description: abdomen between 2-4mm long, possible early instar cockroach nymph
comment: Found inside non commercially packaged sugar beans imported from Zimbabwe

description: 4mm light-dark brown beetle, 11 segmented antenane, stout body, pronounced constriction of the neck
comment: Found amongst new bedding upstairs only
info: Not physically recorded as biosecurity already have a specimen

description: abdomen 2-5mm long, black,
Approx 15mm long (including wings). Long delicately veined translucent wings. Prominent metallic eyes. Body green/brown in colour. Long antennae~7mm.
comment: Found in a car during FIRS inspection on 17.02.18.

location: DoA - out in the dog kennels
description: Just over 1 cm, orange parasitic wasp. Orange in colour
comment: Half a dozen of these wasp species have been reported for the Falklands, all of which are likely to parasitise caterpillars, and particularly those of owlet moths.

location: Seafish Chandlery in the prep room on carrots from Stanley Growers
description: Approx 1 cm long in 9 segments. Brown centipede. Two short antenae possibly tow long legs at the back but one missing. Looks like a common UK centipede.
comment: Found on carrots from Stanley Growers

description: Very flat hard brown shell with eliptical dark brown patch at the front, 8 legs, ~4mm long, short front antennae
comment: ID confirmed by Katie Moon (tick expert in Australia)
info: Found around the outside of the house periodically

description: Coloured mottled brownish-gray, with a yellow orange spot on the dorsal side of the first three abdominal segments. Black dots along each side with orange 'U' shape under each black dot. 2.5 cm long.
comment: Not sure where it was found but among veg

location: Found in soil from Blue Beach
description: Weevil with almost chevron pattern on back. Light brown/black ~1 cm long.
comment: Found when sieving soil sample from Blue Beach farm

description: Some king of ichneumon wasp with distinct black tip on abdomen. Black thorax, orange legs. This specimen missing an antennae and wings a bit destroyed. 1.5cm long.
comment: Found on a windowsill. Maggie does not recall seeing these prior to the 90s.

description: approx 3-5mm in length black/brown/grey colour, distinctive horns on back
Spider, identified as local spider known as a Harvestman
comment: Found outside in the garden near some young camel crickets

description: ~4.5 mm long, small silvery spider. Legs clear/beige with brown spots (tortoiseshell), abdomen grey with mottled white/silver patches.
comment: Found in some locally supplied lettuce (from Tim Miller) so likely to be native/established as the lettuce was grown here

description: Nymph with length of around 2 cm and about 5 mml. Reddish brown colour with a yellowish margin on the pronotum, the body region behind the head. Immature cockroaches resemble adults except they are wingless. Ridges along the back.
comment: Found in a box of pineapples that came in on the LAN flight the previous Saturday. No other cockraoaches were found in the box.Pineapples were subsequently sent offshore to a vessel.

description: Small black/brown spider, slightly toroisehell abdomen, ~8mm body
comment: Found in car container from the UK. Two spiders found.
info: Sent to Alistair Lavery for ID: Could be one of the three Steatoda species that have made there way from UK to the Falklands

description: Colourful ground beetle ~2.5cm long, 6 legs strong jaws. Metallic orange wing casings (elytra) ribbed, metallic green pronotum and head, long antennae (~1cm) in 9 sections.
comment: Found dead in frozen container from the UK (via Uruguay). Found with a similarly coloured but different beetly (ID00521). Found worldwide but mostly in the northern hemisphere.They are common called ‘caterpillar hunters’.
info: Sent to FERA for identification through photos. Fera reference numbers 21808095-6.They can produce a foul-smelling spray from glands near the tip of the abdomen. Fera recently intercepted Calosoma fulgens from Brazil but think this is not quite the same.

description: Beetle just under 2 cm long. Dull metallic green elytra (ribbed), copper pronotum, small delicate antennae
comment: Found dead in frozen container from the UK (via Uruguay). Found with a similarly coloured but different beetle (ID00520).
info: Sent to FERA for identification through photos. Fera reference numbers 21808095-6. It looks as if it is close to the genus Arthrostictus and we have intercepted Arthrostictus speciosus with Brazilian melons.

description: Small black/brown spider, slightly toroisehell abdomen, ~8mm body. Similar to ID00519 and provisionally ID'd via photos by Alistair Lavery as one of three Steatoda sp.introduced from the UK to the Falklands.
comment: Sent sample away to A Lavery for confirmed ID.
info: Found in spare room under carpet.

location: Unknown but found in a puddle
description: Maggots with 'rat tails'.
comment: A characteristic feature of rat-tailed maggots is a tube-like, three-segmented, telescoping breathing siphon located at one end,this acts like a snorkel so it can breath underwater.
info: The most commonly encountered rat-tailed maggots are the larvae of the drone fly, Eristalis tenax. The photos was posted on the DOA facebook page. No specimen brought in.

description: Small beige/light brown caterpillar. ~1.5 - 2cm long. Three 'front legs' and four 'back legs', lighter underneath. Dark brown head. Sparse short black hairs along back.
comment: Found on cabbage from Uruguay. Dead when found.

description: Small white bugs similar to slaters, 0.2 inch (5 mm) long, flat, oval shaped, and have a white waxy covering with wax filaments sticking out from the circumference of the body
comment: Found 5-6 dead in the top of one pomegranate in a batch from Uruguay (via the Scout). Very poor photo taken at the time but bugs not collected. Photo not acceptable for collection but added to common harvest pests folder, see reports
info: Not considered a concern as only found in one fruit (all were checked), they were dead, and no pomegranates of grapes grown here. Fruit was released.

description: Small cockroach either german or asian cockroach, about 1.5 cm long, light tan colour with two dark, roughly parallel, streaks on its head.
comment: Had been spotted in the kitchen a few weeks ago. Area was sprayed and traps set but was caught live today. Was killed so no sample or photos available.
info: Most likely brought back from a fishing vessel.

description: Tiny parasitic wasp, black
comment: Found on green cabbage leaves. One dead. Possible biocontrol used for mealy cabbage aphid.

description: Possibly ladybird larvae
comment: Found on chinese cabbage
info: Stanley growers sold cabbages offshore. Any for town prepared first, washed and outer leaves removed and destroyed.

description: white larvae or maggots 1.5cm in length, white bodies with brown heads.
comment: Found in container of rat bait at Megabid. Floor covered in rat bait and larvae hatching. Found in the middle of winter and larvae still alive, living off the rat bait, which is not poisonous to insects.
info: Could be maggots, could be moth larvae. Unclear how they got into the container though. Maggots more likely as dead mice and rats are in the container.
